key_points: U.S. Rep. Kurt Schrader apologized after comparing possible impeachment of President Trump to a 'lynching'.
Schrader made the comment during a House Democratic caucus call, expressing opposition to impeaching Trump for inciting Capitol riot.
Mark Wiener, a Portland political consultant for Schrader, ended their relationship over the comment.
Wiener criticized Schrader for equating impeachment with lynching, highlighting the insurrection's link to white supremacy.
U.S. Rep. Suzanne Bonamici condemned Schrader's remarks as hurtful and insensitive, emphasizing the nation's history of lynching.
Schrader apologized, acknowledging the historical context and insensitivity of his words.
He has begun reaching out to colleagues to express understanding of the harm caused and to rebuild trust.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced plans to impeach President Trump, urging his immediate resignation.
Schrader, a moderate Democrat, had previously diverged from party lines, notably on stimulus check increases.
Despite a primary challenge, Schrader was reelected in November, representing a district including Portland suburbs and parts of Oregon.
spokespersons: U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-California
